Dune 0.99.2
  • Get started
  • Reference

Perform the ARI merging

Dune.Rd

Compute the ARI between every pair of clustering labels after merging every possible pair of clusters. Find the one that improves the ARI merging the most, merge the pair. Repeat until there is no improvement.

Dune(clusMat, unclustered = NULL, nCores = 1, verbose = FALSE)

Arguments

clusMat

the matrix of samples by clustering labels.
unclustered

The value assigned to unclustered cells. Default to NULL
nCores

number of cores to use when parallelizing. Relies on mclapply. Default to 1.
verbose

Whether or not the print cluster merging as it happens.

Value

A list with four components: the initial matrix of clustering labels, the final matrix of clustering labels, the merge info matrix and the ARI improvement vector.

Details

The Dune algorithm merges pairs of clusters in order to improve the mean adjusted Rand Index with other clustering labels. It returns a list with four components.: #'

  • initialMat: The initial matrix of cluster labels

  • currentMat: The final matrix of cluster labels

  • merges: The step-by-step detail of the merges, recapitulating which clusters where merged in which cluster label

  • impARI: How much each merge improved the mean ARI between the cluster label that has been merged and the other cluster labels.

See also

clusterConversion ARIImp

Examples

data("clusMat", package = "Dune")
merger <- Dune(clusMat = clusMat)
# clusters 11 to 14 from cluster label 5 and 3 are subset of cluster 2 from
# other cluster labels. Designing cluster 2 as unclustered stops the merge of those.
merger2 <- Dune(clusMat = clusMat, unclustered = 2)
merger$merges
#>   clusteringLabel cluster1 cluster2
#> 1               B       11       12
#> 2               C       11       12
#> 3               D       11       13
#> 4               E       11       13
#> 5               E       11       14
#> 6               D       11       12
#> 7               E       11       12
merger2$merges
#>   clusteringLabel cluster1 cluster2
#> 1               B       11       12
#> 2               C       11       12
#> 3               D       11       13
#> 4               E       11       13
#> 5               E       11       14
#> 6               D       11       12
#> 7               E       11       12
